title: Beef Tallow May Soon Show Up On a Menu Near You. Here's What That Means
snippets: Beef tallow, a form of beef fat, is becoming more popular in U.S. restaurants, including Steak 'n Shake, for its flavor and perceived health benefits. However, nutritionists caution that seed oils might be healthier due to lower saturated fatty acids. Datassential predicts beef tallow will appear on 8% of restaurant menus in four years, up from less than 1% currently. The trend reflects a growing demand for less processed foods and a shift away from seed oils, despite the higher cost of beef tallow compared to other fats like duck fat.
summary: Beef tallow, a type of beef fat, is gaining popularity in U.S. restaurants for its taste and health benefits, with usage expected to rise from less than 1% to 8% of menus in four years. Nutritionists, however, suggest seed oils may be healthier due to lower saturated fats. The trend towards beef tallow reflects a preference for less processed foods and a move away from seed oils, despite its higher cost compared to fats like duck fat.
